PhyMediumComments: black-and-white: Agfa Superpan Supreme safety film
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper June 26, 1943, pg. 1, reads: "The above photo is reminiscent of happier days for the Bill 'Bojangles' Robinsons, famous tap dancer and his wife, for last week Mrs. Robinson secured a divorce in the Reno (Nevada) courts. She charged the dancer and screen star with 'mental cruelty.'"Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, National Edition, December 3, 1949, pg. 13, reads: "First Wife - The redoubtable Bill is shown with his first wife, Fannie, a popular New York socialite. Robinson was at the height of his career and did not look a day older than thirty when this photo was taken."Robinson actually had three wives, he was married to Lena Chase 1907-1922; Fannie Clay 1922-1943; Elaine Plaines 1944 until his death in 1949.
TitMainTitle: Bill "Bojangles" Robinson wearing plaid suit, leaning over his wife, Fannie Clay Robinson seated in wooden armchair, in domestic interior with furs on bed in foreground
